pullRequest.title: Inferring spans with async-profiler
pullRequest.bodyText:
Supersedes #972
Closes #971
Checklist


 Implement code
 Add tests
 Update documentation
 Update CHANGELOG.asciidoc
 Update supported-technologies.asciidoc
 Added an API method or config option? Document in which version this will be introduced.
 Added an instrumentation plugin? How did you make sure that old, non-supported versions are not instrumented by accident?

commit.message: Don't validate schema of inferred spans in integration tests

Introduce profiling sessions

Also process events based on timestamp with a MessagePassingQueue

Early POC to use async-profiler to correlate apm traces with profiling data

Some obstacles:
- Can't use plain text trace format because it does not include the timestamp of the events.
  There's an issue and prototype for the plain-text format:
  https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/issues/191
  - JFR output could potentially work
    - ids for distinct stack trace
    - records event metadata: thread id timestamp, stack trace id
    - The thread state in JFR file is always RUNNABLE, even when {@code -e wall} is active
      https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/issues/279
- Uses native thread ids, not java thread ids
  While async-profiler is capable of creating stack traces per thread,
  it reports the native thread ID (which is not equal to `java.lang.Thread#getId()`.
  Probably best to correlate by thread name which is reported (however not in JFR format)
  https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/issues/277
  https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/issues/252
- For some reason exporting jfr files not working with the Java API
  https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/issues/278
There are some more caveats which is the reason why we would still need a fallback to `java.lang.management.ThreadMXBean#dumpAllThreads`:
- Doesn't work on windows
- Limitations on profiling in containers: https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler#profiling-java-in-a-container
  By default, Docker container restricts the access to perf_event_open syscall.
  - Workaround: `-e itimer` profiling mode is similar to cpu mode, but does not require perf_events support.
    As a drawback, there will be no kernel stack traces.
  - Is there something similar for `-e wall`? Is setting `--all-user` enough?

Don't call threadMXBean.getThreadInfo thread id array is empty

To avoid IllegalArgumentException
Populate span.stacktrace, duration and timestamp based on nano timestamps as opposed to ticks
Strongly instead of stringly type StackFrames
Use same timestamp for processing events and stack traces

Use RingBuffer instead of Queue for activation events

The RingBuffer also acts as an object pool.
The idea is that the number of activation events should not impact
the allocation rate, only the profiler_sampling_interval should.
That's currently not completely true
as processing activation events requires copying the TraceContext.
Decrease size of ActivationEvent from 792B to 176B and increase RingBuffer size

Make processing ActivationEvents (almost) garbage free

- Recycle CallTree.Roots
- Only if an activation is actually relevant for the CallTree,
  there will be an allocation
Fist inferred span should have no stack trace
Remove thread-dumping profiler in favor of async-profiler

Don't resolve symbols of excluded classes and methods

reduces allocations

Write ActivationEvents into memory-mapped file

This file can hold up to 100k events and is around 10mb in size
Use primitive collections from Agrona and recycle JfrParser to minimize allocations

Update async-profiler

getNativeThreadId() returns the id of the current thread now
Load async-profiler library based on os and arch

Fix for the edge case when there's a non-shaded profiler in the bootstrap CL

Also loads the native library in an isolated CL as opposed to the bootstrap CL
Give credit where credit is due

Add documentation and changelog

also changes some config option names

nodes.bodyText: Leftovers?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -85,6 +85,8 @@ public void setUp(Blackhole blackhole) throws IOException {
                     .add(CoreConfiguration.ACTIVE, Boolean.toString(apmEnabled))
                     .add("api_request_size", "10mb")

+//                     .add("profiling_inferred_spans", "true")

nodes.bodyText: Extract, together with getLong, into a util class in the utils package.
Is it actually used?

I think it would make more sense to return the length of read bytes, rather than the end position of the reading action (which represent a state of the reader), but not something I would insist. In any case- javadoc would be nice here.

Would ClassFileLocator.ForClassLoader.ofSystemLoader() locate bootstrap classes? Wouldn't .redefine(DirectNativeBinding.class) (which is equivalent to using the locator ClassFileLocator.ForClassLoader.of(DirectNativeBinding.class.getClassLoader())) be safer?
Also, the redefine method javadoc says:

Byte Buddy might be forced to add a method if a redefined class already defines a class initializer.

which the redefine class does. I can't see why this would be a problem, just worth mentioning in case you can.

nodes.bodyText: Consider adding a single-thread object pool for those
Consider adding time measurement of the processing and add a debug log
I think this calls for Symbol's polymorphism - either a MethodSymbol and a ClassSymbol implementing a Symbol or a Symbol class and a ClassSymbol subclass.
Consider pooling StackFrames and use them with StringBuilders instead of Strings for class and method names, into which you can directly resolve from the file.
This makes it dynamic only when starting with true. If you remove this check it will be completely dynamic, as you check at the beginning of each run invocation.

Is this required? If you always parse activation events in the right order, then the state of the profiledThreads map should always indicate whether an activation event for a thread is a root or not- if there is one for the thread, it is not a root, otherwise it is. Am I missing something?
Consider pooling CallTree objects.
Log if it IS null

Add a few words on each, at least traceContext, activeSpan and activeSpanSerialized. It will make it easier to understand.
Can you reuse CallTree#activeContext instead of using activeSpan, or is it used to reflect a special root state (where activeContext is never set)?
Wouldn't traceContext better be called rootContext?
It would very useful if you add a detailed explanation about the algorithm as a javadoc of this method. Not all corner-cases handled, but the general concept.

I think we should also avoid creating spans when count < 2. If we take snapshots every 20 ms in a 2-second transaction, we may get 100 non-informative spans. More importantly, when someone will compare traces to one another they will seem as there are many arbitrary areas with random spans.
What's the benefit over the queue-based pool?

+public class ListBasedObjectPool<T> extends AbstractObjectPool<T> {
+
+    private final List<T> pool;

nodes.bodyText: If you find an easy and cheap way (i.e. without getting the full stack trace) to get Transaction's frame in the root, you can cut all the unnecessary call tree "trunk".
Let's not call it profiler, we already know how people can misuse this...
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -378,13 +378,29 @@ If you are seeing gaps in the span timeline and want to include certain methods,
 |Less flexible on it's own but can be combined with the API.
  Just get the <<api-current-span, current span>> on an annotated method and customize the span to your liking.
 
-|Configuration
+|Sampling-based profiler (incubating) added[1.13.0]
+|Leverages https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler[async-profiler]
+ to periodically record which methods are running (stack traces).
+ Enable by setting <<config-profiling-spans-enabled, `profiling_spans_enabled`>> to `true`.
+|Very low overhead, no code changes required.
+ Great to find out which parts of the code make your application slow,
+ without having to apply application-specific configuration.
+|Does not work on Windows.
+ Only creates spans while a profiling session is ongoing.
+ This can be controlled via <<config-profiling-duration, `profiling_duration`>> and <<config-profiling-interval, `profiling_interval`>>.
+ The duration of profiler-inferred spans are not exact measurements, only estimates.
+ The accuracy depends on <<config-profiling-sampling-interval, `profiling_sampling_interval`>>.
+
+|Instrumentation-based profiler

 * Instrument log4j Logger#error(String, Throwable) ({pull}919[#919]) Automatically captures exceptions when calling `logger.error("message", exception)`
 * Add instrumentation for external process execution through `java.lang.Process` and Apache `commons-exec` - {pull}903[#903]
 * Add `destination` fields to exit span contexts - {pull}976[#976]

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1204,6 +1218,173 @@ Prepending an element with `(?-i)` makes the matching case sensitive.
 | `elastic.apm.ignore_message_queues` | `ignore_message_queues` | `ELASTIC_APM_IGNORE_MESSAGE_QUEUES`
 |============
 
+[[config-profiling]]
+=== Profiling configuration options
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-spans-enabled]]
+==== `profiling_spans_enabled` (added[1.13.0])
+
+Set to `true` to make the agent create spans for method executions based on
+https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler[async-profiler], a sampling aka statistical profiler.
+
+If this is enabled, the agent will start a profiling session every
+<<config-profiling-interval, `profiling_interval`>> which lasts for <<config-profiling-duration, `profiling_duration`>>.
+If a transaction happens within a profiling session,
+the agent creates spans for slow methods.
+
+Note that due to the nature of how sampling profilers work,
+the duration of the inferred spans are not exact, but only estimations.
+The <<config-profiling-sampling-interval, `profiling_sampling_interval`>> lets you fine tune the trade-off between accuracy and overhead.
+
+NOTE: This feature is not available on Windows
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Default                          | Type                | Dynamic
+| `false` | Boolean | true
+|============
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Java System Properties      | Property file   | Environment
+| `elastic.apm.profiling_spans_enabled` | `profiling_spans_enabled` | `ELASTIC_APM_PROFILING_SPANS_ENABLED`
+|============
+
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-sampling-interval]]
+==== `profiling_sampling_interval` (added[1.13.0])
+
+The frequency at which stack traces are gathered within a profiling session.
+The lower you set it, the more accurate the durations will be.
+This comes at the expense of higher overhead and more spans for potentially irrelevant operations.
+The minimal duration of a profiling-inferred span is the same as the value of this setting.
+
+Supports the duration suffixes `ms`, `s` and `m`.
+Example: `20ms`.
+The default unit for this option is `ms`

+
+Set to `true` to make the agent create spans for method executions based on
+https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler[async-profiler], a sampling aka statistical profiler.
+
+If this is enabled, the agent will start a profiling session every

+If a transaction happens within a profiling session,
+the agent creates spans for slow methods.
+
+Note that due to the nature of how sampling profilers work,
+the duration of the inferred spans are not exact, but only estimations.
+The <<config-profiling-sampling-interval, `profiling_sampling_interval`>> lets you fine tune the trade-off between accuracy and overhead.

+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============

+| `false` | Boolean | true
+|============

+
+[options="header"]
+|============

+| `elastic.apm.profiling_spans_enabled` | `profiling_spans_enabled` | `ELASTIC_APM_PROFILING_SPANS_ENABLED`
+|============
+
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-sampling-interval]]
+==== `profiling_sampling_interval` (added[1.13.0])
+
+The frequency at which stack traces are gathered within a profiling session.
+The lower you set it, the more accurate the durations will be.
+This comes at the expense of higher overhead and more spans for potentially irrelevant operations.
+The minimal duration of a profiling-inferred span is the same as the value of this setting.
+
+Supports the duration suffixes `ms`, `s` and `m`.
+Example: `20ms`.
+The default unit for this option is `ms`
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Default                          | Type                | Dynamic
+| `20ms` | TimeDuration | true
+|============
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Java System Properties      | Property file   | Environment
+| `elastic.apm.profiling_sampling_interval` | `profiling_sampling_interval` | `ELASTIC_APM_PROFILING_SAMPLING_INTERVAL`
+|============
+
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-included-classes]]
+==== `profiling_included_classes` (added[1.13.0])
+
+If set, the agent will only create inferred spans for methods which match this list.
+Setting a value may slightly increase performance and can reduce clutter by only creating spans for the classes you are interested in.
+Example: `org.example.myapp.*`
+
+This option supports the wildcard `*`, which matches zero or more characters.
+Examples: `/foo/*/bar/*/baz*`, `*foo*`.
+Matching is case insensitive by default.
+Prepending an element with `(?-i)` makes the matching case sensitive.
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Default                          | Type                | Dynamic
+| `*` | List | true
+|============
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Java System Properties      | Property file   | Environment
+| `elastic.apm.profiling_included_classes` | `profiling_included_classes` | `ELASTIC_APM_PROFILING_INCLUDED_CLASSES`
+|============
+
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-excluded-classes]]
+==== `profiling_excluded_classes` (added[1.13.0])
+
+Excludes classes for which no profiler-inferred spans should be created.
+
+This option supports the wildcard `*`, which matches zero or more characters.
+Examples: `/foo/*/bar/*/baz*`, `*foo*`.
+Matching is case insensitive by default.
+Prepending an element with `(?-i)` makes the matching case sensitive.
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Default                          | Type                | Dynamic
+| `(?-i)java.*, (?-i)javax.*, (?-i)sun.*, (?-i)com.sun.*, (?-i)jdk.*` | List | true
+|============
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Java System Properties      | Property file   | Environment
+| `elastic.apm.profiling_excluded_classes` | `profiling_excluded_classes` | `ELASTIC_APM_PROFILING_EXCLUDED_CLASSES`
+|============
+
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-interval]]
+==== `profiling_interval` (added[1.13.0])
+
+The interval at which profiling sessions should be started.
+
+Supports the duration suffixes `ms`, `s` and `m`.
+Example: `61s`.
+The default unit for this option is `s`

+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Java System Properties      | Property file   | Environment
+| `elastic.apm.profiling_included_classes` | `profiling_included_classes` | `ELASTIC_APM_PROFILING_INCLUDED_CLASSES`
+|============
+
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-excluded-classes]]
+==== `profiling_excluded_classes` (added[1.13.0])
+
+Excludes classes for which no profiler-inferred spans should be created.
+
+This option supports the wildcard `*`, which matches zero or more characters.
+Examples: `/foo/*/bar/*/baz*`, `*foo*`.
+Matching is case insensitive by default.
+Prepending an element with `(?-i)` makes the matching case sensitive.
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Default                          | Type                | Dynamic
+| `(?-i)java.*, (?-i)javax.*, (?-i)sun.*, (?-i)com.sun.*, (?-i)jdk.*` | List | true
+|============
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Java System Properties      | Property file   | Environment
+| `elastic.apm.profiling_excluded_classes` | `profiling_excluded_classes` | `ELASTIC_APM_PROFILING_EXCLUDED_CLASSES`
+|============
+
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-interval]]
+==== `profiling_interval` (added[1.13.0])
+
+The interval at which profiling sessions should be started.
+
+Supports the duration suffixes `ms`, `s` and `m`.
+Example: `61s`.
+The default unit for this option is `s`
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Default                          | Type                | Dynamic
+| `61s` | TimeDuration | true
+|============
+
+
+[options="header"]
+|============
+| Java System Properties      | Property file   | Environment
+| `elastic.apm.profiling_interval` | `profiling_interval` | `ELASTIC_APM_PROFILING_INTERVAL`
+|============
+
+// This file is auto generated. Please make your changes in *Configuration.java (for example CoreConfiguration.java) and execute ConfigurationExporter
+[float]
+[[config-profiling-duration]]
+==== `profiling_duration` (added[1.13.0])
+
+The duration of a profiling session.
+For sampled transactions which fall within a profiling session (they start after and end before the session),
+so-called inferred spans will be created.
+They appear in the trace waterfall view like regular spans.
+
+Supports the duration suffixes `ms`, `s` and `m`.
+Example: `10s`.
+The default unit for this option is `s`

commit.message:
Limit depth of call tree to 256

The limit is somewhat arbitrary and maybe even too conservative.
Can't really decide between 512 and 256.
The idea behind is to limit the depth so the recursive algorithms on
the CallTree don't cause StackOverflowErrors and also to limit allocations.

Update async-profiler

to include fix for https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/issues/290

Load libasyncProfiler.so lazily

avoids loading the lib if profiling is off
while still allowing to dynamically turn on profiling
Increase max size and pre-allocate first 10mb of activation events file
Make sure there's a log if async-profiler can't load
Test inferred spans in integration tests
Disable async-profiler test on J9-based tests

Remove flaky inferred span integration test

Still start the integration tests with the profiler on
to test for obvious errors like segfaults

nodes.bodyText: Isn't it the other way round? Smaller interval => higher accuracy
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,182 @@
+/*-
+ * #%L
+ * Elastic APM Java agent

+ * "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY
+ * KIND, either express or implied.  See the License for the
+ * specific language governing permissions and limitations
+ * under the License.
+ * #L%
+ */
+package co.elastic.apm.agent.profiler;
+
+import co.elastic.apm.agent.configuration.converter.ListValueConverter;
+import co.elastic.apm.agent.configuration.converter.TimeDuration;
+import co.elastic.apm.agent.configuration.converter.TimeDurationValueConverter;
+import co.elastic.apm.agent.matcher.WildcardMatcher;
+import co.elastic.apm.agent.matcher.WildcardMatcherValueConverter;
+import org.stagemonitor.configuration.ConfigurationOption;
+import org.stagemonitor.configuration.ConfigurationOptionProvider;
+
+import java.util.Arrays;
+import java.util.List;
+
+import static co.elastic.apm.agent.configuration.validation.RangeValidator.isInRange;
+import static co.elastic.apm.agent.configuration.validation.RangeValidator.min;
+
+public class ProfilingConfiguration extends ConfigurationOptionProvider {
+
+    private static final String PROFILING_CATEGORY = "Profiling";
+
+    private final ConfigurationOption<Boolean> profilingEnabled = ConfigurationOption.<Boolean>booleanOption()
+        .key("profiling_spans_enabled")
+        .configurationCategory(PROFILING_CATEGORY)
+        .description("Set to `true` to make the agent create spans for method executions based on\n" +
+            "https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler[async-profiler], a sampling aka statistical profiler.\n" +
+            "\n" +
+            "If this is enabled, the agent will start a profiling session every\n" +
+            "<<config-profiling-interval, `profiling_interval`>> which lasts for <<config-profiling-duration, `profiling_duration`>>.\n" +
+            "If a transaction happens within a profiling session,\n" +
+            "the agent creates spans for slow methods.\n" +
+            "\n" +
+            "Due to the nature of how sampling profilers work,\n" +
+            "the duration of the inferred spans are not exact, but only estimations.\n" +
+            "The <<config-profiling-sampling-interval, `profiling_sampling_interval`>> lets you fine tune the trade-off between accuracy and overhead.\n" +
+            "\n" +
+            "The inferred spans are created after a profiling session has ended.\n" +
+            "This means there is a delay between the regular and the inferred spans being visible in the UI.\n" +
+            "\n" +
+            "NOTE: This feature is not available on Windows")
+        .tags("experimental")
+        .dynamic(true)
+        .tags("added[1.13.0]")
+        .buildWithDefault(false);
+
+    private final ConfigurationOption<TimeDuration> samplingInterval = TimeDurationValueConverter.durationOption("ms")
+        .key("profiling_sampling_interval")
+        .configurationCategory(PROFILING_CATEGORY)
+        .dynamic(true)
+        .description("The frequency at which stack traces are gathered within a profiling session.\n" +
+            "The lower you set it, the more accurate the durations will be.\n" +
+            "This comes at the expense of higher overhead and more spans for potentially irrelevant operations.\n" +
+            "The minimal duration of a profiling-inferred span is the same as the value of this setting.")
+        .addValidator(isInRange(TimeDuration.of("1ms"), TimeDuration.of("1s")))
+        .tags("added[1.13.0]")
+        .buildWithDefault(TimeDuration.of("20ms"));
+
+    private final ConfigurationOption<TimeDuration> inferredSpansMinDuration = TimeDurationValueConverter.durationOption("ms")
+        .key("profiling_spans_min_duration")
+        .configurationCategory(PROFILING_CATEGORY)
+        .dynamic(true)
+        .description("The minimum duration of an inferred span.\n" +
+            "Note that the min duration is also implicitly set by the sampling interval.\n" +
+            "However, decreasing the sampling interval also decreases the accuracy of the duration of inferred spans.")

nodes.bodyText:
I'm going to re-implement the way how native methods are bound, so that no fancy layers will be needed. It's possible to make it work without instrumentation or dynamic class generation.
Furthermore, the number of native methods will be likely reduced to the minimum required. E.g. all dumpXXX stuff can be implemented on top of execute0.

There are definitely more platforms where async-profiler works, e.g. x64-musl and AArch64. Probably, more platforms in future - there is already a PR for PPC port, for example. Not sure if packing all binaries into a single .jar is a good idea.
Also, it's not enough to look only at these two properties to distinguish glibc from musl libc.

Although async-profiler currently writes everything within a single checkpoint, JFR format can possibly have many checkpoints. In order to support continuous profiling, both JFR reader and writer should consider multiple checkpoints.
There are plans to support at least two states: RUNNABLE and SLEEPING, depending on whether the thread is currently on cpu or not.

Writing to a (large) MappedByteBuffer is somewhat guileful. Any put() operation may potentially get stuck, and not only in writing thread, but also cause long global time-to-safepoint pause.
In this sense, writing to a temporary direct ByteBuffer and then flushing with a regular write() call is safer.
Sleeping even if there is more data to process - is it intentional?
IMO, a regular List, sorted afterwards, will be more space-efficient, and will preserve StackTraceEvents with duplicate timestamps (although they are unlikely).
Matching Java threads by native id looks a bit hacky. It probably makes sense for async-profiler to record Java thread id, too.

Maybe switch to using the binary header functionalities for serialization (fillOutgoingTraceParentBinaryHeader) and deserialization (asChildOf(byte[])), with an extended byte array where you separately serialize/deserialize the clock and service name? Just so we don't need to maintain both

commit.message:
Check if frames from async-profiler are non-empty before adding to call tree

Otherwise, we'd prematurely end branches
See also https://github.com/jvm-profiling-tools/async-profiler/issues/271#issuecomment-582430233
Only profile threads with active transactions
Don't use memory mapped file to read activation events
Increase activation events direct buffer to ~100kb
Use a moving DirectByteBuffer instead of MappedByteBuffer to read the file

nodes.bodyText: Seems like we read redundant 4MB at the beginning, since after getting metadata offset, we immediately seek to the end of the file. Probably, read can accept another parameter - the maximum number of bytes to read.
A small note: RandomAccessFile is redundant, when it is used only to get FileChannel. You may directly call FileChannel.open instead.

I'd add & 0xffff to convert this to an unsigned short.
There hardly be a string larger than 32K, but just in case.
The same in skipString.

commit.message:
Make sure to not read redundant 4mb at the beginning

- Remove RandomAccessFile with FileChannel.open
- convert string length to unsigned short

nodes.bodyText: 0xffff

commit.message:
Update to async-profiler 1.7.0-ea2

- Fix restoring thread filter
- async-profiler now includes Java thread id in the JFR file
  we can get rid of mapping native thread ids to Java thread ids
- Make SamplingProfilerTest more reliable
- Fix bug in when removing thread from filter
Don't write to disk if activation events fit into memory (4k events)
Use ThreadGroup.enumerate to restore filter state
Add benchmarks, performance improvements if file is larger than buffer

Update to async-profiler 1.7.0-ea3

- disable native frames
  for the inferred spans use case, we're only interested in Java frames
  disabling native frames reduces the JFR file size and reduces the profiling overhead a little
- remove Byte Buddy shading hack

Recycle on end

- siginificantly reduces allocations
- makes CallTree pool more effective

Release resources when not profiling

- respect `active` config option
- clear object pools
- make JfrParser GC eligible
Avoid recycling of CallTrees while still needed in tests
Attempt to fix service name mismatch
